name.text: 19.1.2.1 The general solution of a differential equation

questiontext.text:
The general solution of a differential equation

Consider the equation \(y=A \text{e}^{2x}\) where \(A\) is an arbitrary constant. If we differentiate it we obtain \[ {dy\over dx}=2A\text{e}^{2x}\] and so, since \[y=A\text{e}^{2x}\] we obtain \[ {dy\over {dx}}=2y.\] Thus a differential equation satisfied by \(y\) is \[{dy\over dx}=2y.\] Note that we have eliminated the arbitrary constant.

Now consider the equation \[y=A\cos 3x+B\sin 3x\] where \(A\) and \(B\) are arbitrary constants. Differentiating, we obtain \[ {dy\over dx}=-3A\sin 3x+3B\cos 3x.\]

Differentiating a second time gives \[ {d^2y\over dx^2}=-9\,A\cos 3x-9\,B\sin 3x.\] The right-hand side is simply \((-9)\) times the expression for \(y\). Hence \(y\) satisfies the differential equation \[ {d^2y\over dx^2}=-9y.\]
